snippet: Shinzo Abe’s compromise on the Yasukuni Shrine was meant to satisfy his right-wing base without inflaming passions in the region.
abstract: Japan’s hawkish new Prime Min Shinzo Abe observes anniversary of his nation’s defeat in World War II by sending an offering to a controversial Tokyo war shrine instead of visiting it himself; compromise move is meant to satisfy his right-wing base without inflaming passions in the region.

byline.contributor: Hisako Ueno contributed reporting from Tokyo, Choe Sang-hun from Seoul, South Korea, and Chris Buckley from Hong Kong. Bree Feng contributed research from Beijing.

lead_paragraph: Shinzo Abe’s compromise on the Yasukuni Shrine was meant to satisfy his right-wing base without inflaming passions in the region.

headline.main: Japan’s Premier Stays Away From War Shrine, but Sends Offering
headline.print_headline: Japan’s Premier Stays Away From War Shrine, but Sends Offering
